thread.title: OCS hosts Mangham for district lead
thread.title_full: OCS hosts Mangham for district lead

title: OCS hosts Mangham for district lead
text:
OCS hosts Mangham for district lead Final two unbeatens in District 2-2A meet at Ouachita Christian Post to Facebook OCS hosts Mangham for district lead Final two unbeatens in District 2-2A meet at Ouachita Christian Check out this story on thenewsstar.com: http://tnsne.ws/1RX7hKJ Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Conversation 18 CONNECT 8 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Given four quality, nearby programs thrown into the same district as Sterlington, Rayville, Mangham and Ouachita Christian were this season, it’s reasonable to expect a season-long race for the district championship. 
Two weeks in, the picture is surprisingly clear. When Mangham travels to Ouachita Christian for Friday’s game, they will meet as the final two teams with 2-0 records in district play. The winner is just two wins away from taking the district outright. 
“We know it. Right now, we’re 2-0 and they’re 2-0 in district. Whoever wins this game is in the driver’s seat for the district championship,” Ouachita Christian coach Steven Fitzhugh said. “It’s area bragging rights, that’s the thing.” 
Friday culminates a brutal stretch in the schedule for the Eagles, having just won at Sterlington 21-18 then beating Rayville 42-28 at home last week. Those two games came after a 35-28 loss at Alexandria. 
Mangham has had its fair share of excitement of late, as well, beating Sterlington 36-35 in overtime last week on a successful two-point conversion. 
“I guess everybody’s brain can go several different ways after that,” Mangham coach Tommy Tharp said. “You prepare the same way week-in and week-out. You hope you can rebound from an emotional win or emotional loss. Our kids out here and our team’s personality have always been even-keeled. I feel good about where our mind is right now.” 
Tharp also feels good about where his offense is right now, scoring over 35 points in each of its last five games. 
“Our offensive line has really come along,” Tharp said. “We started out, quite frankly, not very good, trying to fill some positions, but we think we’ve filled those positions and maybe developed some depth, too. That’s been a pleasant surprise. Probably what’s been more of a surprise is that we’ve been able to keep depth at running back, keep kids healthy and develop some younger guys.” 
Fitzhugh added of the Mangham offense, “We’ve seen it through the years with them. They run a scheme they learn early and they keep getting better at it from the time they’re in junior high and JV and when they’re on varsity, they have guys that can step in.” 
Tharp knows the Ouachita Christian offense presents its own challenges, too. 
“They are awful talented, and they’re awful multiple,” Tharp said. “They’re probably one of the more balanced teams we play year-in and year-out. You have to be equally sound in playing the run and the pass. 
“It’s never an easy chore stopping them. We’ve never completely shut them down.”
